resources.string: Used for auto-update system to install new versions from GitHub releases. Only used when user explicitly enables auto-updates and app was not installed from Google Play Store.
Required for Bluetooth and WiFi conditional filtering features. Used to detect nearby Bluetooth devices and WiFi networks for user-defined rules. No location tracking or data collection.
Required for Bluetooth conditional filtering. Allows the app to detect when specific Bluetooth devices are connected for notification rules. No data is collected or transmitted.
Required for WiFi network conditional filtering on Android 13+. Allows the app to detect WiFi network changes for user-defined notification rules. No network data is collected.
Used for importing/exporting app settings and configuration files. Allows users to backup and restore their settings. No personal data is accessed.
SpeakThat! needs access to your notifications to read them aloud. This permission is required for the app to function.
üí° Turn off when not needed to save battery

Choose how SpeakThat handles multiple notifications:
üîÑ Interrupt - Stops current notification and reads new one immediately. Best for urgent notifications.
üìã Queue - Finishes current notification, then reads new ones in order. Nothing gets missed.
‚è≠Ô∏è Skip - Ignores new notifications while reading. Simple but you might miss important ones.
üß† Smart (Recommended) - Priority apps interrupt, others queue. Perfect balance of urgency and completeness.
Smart mode lets you choose which apps are urgent enough to interrupt (like calls, messages) while other apps wait their turn.
Customize how app names are spoken in notifications
Example: X app reads as Twitter

Choose how SpeakThat handles notifications while music/videos play:
üéµ Ignore - Speaks over your media. Simple but can be disruptive.
‚è∏Ô∏è Pause - Pauses media completely while speaking. Good for podcasts, but interrupts music flow.
üîâ Lower Audio (Recommended) - Temporarily reduces media volume so you can hear both. Most natural experience.
üîá Silence - Doesn\'t speak while media plays. Quiet but you might miss important notifications.
Lower Audio works like a car radio - it ducks the music down when speaking, then brings it back up. Perfect for music lovers who still want notifications.

Shake to Stop lets you instantly silence SpeakThat by shaking your device:
‚ú® Why it\'s helpful: ‚Ä¢ Stop embarrassing notifications in quiet places ‚Ä¢ Quick control when your hands are busy ‚Ä¢ Works even when screen is off ‚Ä¢ No fumbling for buttons
üéØ How it works: ‚Ä¢ Shake your device firmly (like a dice shake) ‚Ä¢ Current notification stops immediately ‚Ä¢ Queued notifications are cleared ‚Ä¢ New notifications work normally
‚öôÔ∏è Customization: ‚Ä¢ Adjust sensitivity for your preference ‚Ä¢ Test your shake strength with the meter ‚Ä¢ Works great for both gentle and vigorous shakers
This feature is especially loved by people who get notifications during meetings, movies, or while driving.
Skip notifications that are persistent (ongoing) or silent (no sound/vibration)

üí° Persistent notifications are ongoing (like music controls, navigation, etc.) and silent notifications have no sound/vibration. This option helps reduce notification spam from background services.
Ongoing notifications that don\'t auto-dismiss (music controls, navigation)
Notifications with no sound or vibration
Notifications with minimum or low priority level
Notifications from system apps (Android, Google services)

Wave to Stop lets you instantly silence SpeakThat by waving your hand in front of the device:
‚ú® Why it\'s helpful: ‚Ä¢ Perfect for users who can\'t shake their device ‚Ä¢ Great for phones on desks or mounts ‚Ä¢ Works with one hand ‚Ä¢ No physical device movement needed ‚Ä¢ Accessibility-friendly alternative to shake
üéØ How it works: ‚Ä¢ Wave your hand in front of the device (like a magic gesture) ‚Ä¢ Uses the proximity sensor to detect hand movement ‚Ä¢ Current notification stops immediately ‚Ä¢ Queued notifications are cleared ‚Ä¢ New notifications work normally
‚öôÔ∏è Customization: ‚Ä¢ Adjust sensitivity for your preference ‚Ä¢ Test your wave detection with the meter ‚Ä¢ Works great for different hand sizes and distances
This feature is especially useful for accessibility, desk users, and anyone who prefers gesture control over physical movement.
This version of SpeakThat! receives updates through your app store (F-Droid, Google Play Store, etc.).
‚Ä¢ Updates are automatically handled by your app store\n‚Ä¢ You\'ll receive notifications when updates are available\n‚Ä¢ No manual download or installation required
If you want automatic updates directly from GitHub, you can download the GitHub version instead. This version is identical but includes auto-update functionality.

SpeakThat! is an open-source Android Notification Reader that announces your notifications aloud using text-to-speech. Perfect for hands-free operation, accessibility, and staying informed while multitasking.

‚Ä¢ Real-time notification reading
‚Ä¢ Customizable voice settings
‚Ä¢ Smart notification filtering
‚Ä¢ App-specific controls
‚Ä¢ Media-aware behavior
‚Ä¢ Notification history
‚Ä¢ Shake/Wave to stop
‚Ä¢ Custom speech formatting
‚Ä¢ Dark/Light theme support
‚Ä¢ Conditional rules for advanced logic and schedules
‚Ä¢ Fully ad-free and offline functionality

Developed with ‚ù§Ô∏è by Mitchi, a solo developer from the UK with over 12 years of experience testing and using notification readers every day.

SpeakThat! was inspired by Touchless Notifications, originally developed by DYNA Logix, and aims to carry forth the legacy of customisable notification readers.

This project was accelerated by AI-assisted programming.
This project is open source and available under the GPL-3.0 License.\n\nYou can view the full license text and source code on GitHub. Contributions and feedback are welcome!

SpeakThat is an open-source Android Notification Reader that announces your notifications aloud using text-to-speech. Perfect for hands-free operation, accessibility, and staying informed while multitasking.

Real-time notification reading, customizable voice settings, smart notification filtering, app-specific controls, media-aware behavior, notification history tracking, Shake to Stop and Wave to Stop, custom speech formatting, dark mode and light mode support, conditional rules for advanced logic and schedules, and fully ad-free, offline functionality.

Developed with love by Mitchi, a solo developer from the UK with over 12 years of experience testing and using notification readers every day. SpeakThat was inspired by Touchless Notifications, originally developed by DYNA Logix, and aims to carry forth the legacy of customisable notification readers. This project was accelerated by Artificial Intelligence assisted programming.
This project is open source and available under the GPL-3.0 License. You can view the full license text and source code on GitHub. Contributions and feedback are welcome!
Your app is up to date!
Download version %s? This will use mobile data if not on WiFi.
Privacy: Update checks only verify version numbers. No personal data is collected or transmitted.
Automatically check for app updates when you open the app
How often should the app check for updates?

This will reset all settings to defaults and clear notification history.

These settings are for users who need granular control over the voice and accent.

99% of users should only change the main Language option.

If you run into trouble, you can always reset to defaults.
